means: [人名] [英格兰人姓氏] 博伊科特住所名称，来源于古英语人名Boia+“蔽身之处，农舍”(shelter,cottage)

sentence.Network_en: Opposition leaders had called for a boycott of the vote.
sentence.Network_cn: 反对党领袖已号召人们拒绝投票。

sentence.Network_en: Rosie Boycott was not involved editorially with Virago.
sentence.Network_cn: 罗西·博伊科特不属于维拉戈出版公司的编辑队伍。

sentence.Network_en: We are asking people to boycott goods from companies that use child labour.
sentence.Network_cn: 我们正呼吁大家抵制雇用童工的公司的产品。

derivation.yuyuan_name: from the name of Captain Charles C. Boycott (1832–97), an Irish land agent so treated in 1880, in an attempt instigated by the Irish Land League to get rents reduced

entry.def: If a country, group, or person boycotts a country, organization, or activity, they refuse to be involved with it in any way because they disapprove of it.

example.ex: The main opposition parties are boycotting the elections.
example.tran: 主要反对党都抵制此次选举。

means.word_mean: 1. a group's refusal to have commercial dealings with some organization in protest against its policies
1. refuse to sponsor; refuse to do business with

auth_sentence.content: Some opposition groups had planned to boycott the vote.
auth_sentence.res_content: Some opposition groups had planned to boycott the vote.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: Some opposition groups had planned to boycott the vote.

auth_sentence.content: The military disbanded the party because of the boycott.
auth_sentence.res_content: The military disbanded the party because of the boycott.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: The military disbanded the party because of the boycott.

auth_sentence.content: Palestinians announced a boycott of such products last month.
auth_sentence.res_content: Palestinians announced a boycott of such products last month.

means.word_mean: 拒绝购买（或使用、参加）；抵制

sentences.en: They're boycotting the shop because the people there are on strike.
sentences.cn: 他们抵制那家商店, 因为那里的店员在罢工。

jushi.english: Some of the people determined to boycott the Japanese goods.
